DOC.HEAD: Judge Ponders Theft Issue In Buchwald Suit
DOC.TEXT: A racial issue was raised in closing arguments in a suit accusing Paramount Pictures of plagiarizing Art Buchwald's idea for a story about an African prince for the Eddie Murphy movie, ``Coming to America.'' Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider took the lawsuit under submission Thursday after arguments by Buchwald's lawyer and an attorney for Paramount Pictures. Schneider said he would issue a written ruling ``relatively soon.'' Attorneys said that could mean within three to 15 days. Paramount lawyer Robert Draper drew a mild rebuke from the judge when he tried to inject a racial issue into the lawsuit. ``Eddie Murphy is black and Eddie Murphy is a mega-star, and Eddie Murphy has to make a living,'' attorney Robert Draper began. ``He's not white like Mr. Buchwald. He's not an Eastern establishment writer like Mr. Buchwald.'' At that point, Schneider interrupted the attorney's closing argument. ``I don't perceive this to be a case about race,'' the judge said. ``I disagree with your honor,'' said Draper. But he dropped the subject and moved on to argue there aren't sufficient similarities between Buchwald's script idea, ``King for a Day,'' and Murphy's box office hit, ``Coming to America'' to show that one was based on the other. Attorney Pierce O'Donnell, representing Buchwald, argued there are at least 14 points and perhaps as many as 35 points of similarity between the scripts. Both involve an African member of royalty coming to the United States, living in a ghetto, working at a fast food restaurant, falling in love and taking home a bride. O'Donnell cited Paramount's 1983 contract with Buchwald to produce his brief treatment entitled, ``King for a Day,'' and said it was clearly the inspiration for Murphy's film. Buchwald is seeking $5 million in actual damages and unspecified punitive damages from the studio. ``Hollywood makes movies, but not without ideas,'' O'Donnell declared. ``At minimum, what Paramount bought was an idea, a concept. It was unique. It was original ... as it turned out, this was a $400 million idea.'' Schneider pressed both lawyers to tell him what elements would combine to prove that a movie was based upon another script or idea. He called the issue amorphous and said the evidence had failed to clarify it.
